title: Assisted Collections | Bins and Recycling | Gloucester City Council
text: We may be able to provide a free assisted collection service if you need help to take your waste and recycling containers to the pavement because of mobility difficulties or an impairment and there is no one else in your household. ### ğŸ”„ Assisted collection review **If you have received a review letter, we are aware that some residents didn't receive the form.** If you would like to continue with your assisted collection please email your collection address to [environment@gloucester.gov.uk](mailto:environment@gloucester.gov.uk) You do not need to complete the form on this page. ## Who is eligible ### âœ“ You may be eligible if: * You have mobility difficulties or an impairment that prevents you from taking bins to the pavement * There is no one else in your household who can help * You live in a property with individual bins (not communal bin stores) ### âœ• This service is not available to: * Residents that use communal bin stores * The original person who applied for an assisted collection and is no longer living at the property * Residents that have restricted access for example caravan parks, narrow or private roads, steps or steep driveways, length of driveway or locked gates **Important:** If you are receiving assisted collections but no longer need the service, you must inform us as soon as possible. ## How to apply or cancel an assisted collection ### Apply online (quickest way) Online is the quickest way to apply or cancel an assisted collection. [Apply or cancel online â†’](https://www.gloucester.gov.uk/environment-waste-recycling/waste-recycling-street-cleaning/bins-recycling/assisted-collections/) ### ğŸ“ Other ways to apply or cancel Please phone us on **[01452 396 396](tel:+441452396396)** if you cannot use the online service. ## Important information ### ğŸ“‹ Proof of eligibility We may ask for proof of eligibility and we reserve the right to suspend or withdraw this service at any time although we would notify you if the service was to be withdrawn.

title: Check your bin collection day | Bins and Recycling | Gloucester City Council
text: Enter your postcode to find out which bins are collected when at your property. ## How to put your bins out **By 7am on collection day** Put bins out the evening before â€” collections can start early **At the boundary of your property** Where your drive meets the pavement, or at your garden gate **Where crew can reach them** Crews cannot enter your property or open gates **Lid must close fully** Overfilled bins may not be collected **Bring back within 24 hours** Don't leave bins on the pavement after collection ## What if my bin isn't collected? **Check it wasn't refused** Was the lid closed? Was it in the right place? Wrong items inside? **Check for service updates** Bad weather or vehicle breakdowns can delay collections **Give crews until end of day** Crews can be out until 5pm, so your bin may still be collected **Report by 4pm the next business day** If still not collected, [report a missed collection](https://gloucester.gov.uk/bins/missed-collection.html) by 4pm the next business day and we'll return within 2 working days **âš¡ We'll return within 2 working days** after you report a missed collection. ## Set up reminders After looking up your collection days above, you can: * **Add dates to your calendar** â€” Subscribe to an automatically updating calendar feed * **Email or SMS reminders** â€” Get notified the evening before each collection * **Download PDF** â€” Keep a copy of your collection schedule ğŸ’¡ **Tip:** Look up your postcode above to see reminder options for your address.

title: Apply or Renew an Extra or Larger Black Bin | Bins and Recycling | Gloucester City Council
text:
You can get an extra or larger black bin if you're recycling everything you can by making full use of the recycling containers and if any of the following apply to you. ## Who is eligible ### âœ“ You may be eligible if: * **7 or more residents** registered at the property * **2 or more children under the age of 3** and still wearing nappies Have you heard about the [Gloucestershire Real Nappy Project](https://www.gloucester.gov.uk/media/vlqbs2ce/gloucestershire-real-nappy-project.pdf) (PDF, 8.3 MB) * **Certain medical conditions** that generate additional waste ### âš ï¸ Important: Before you apply **If you're having problems managing your waste and don't meet the criteria, please ensure you are making full use of the weekly recycling service.** For us to assess your application you must be recycling your waste by having a minimum of: * 2 recycling boxes * 1 blue sack * 1 large food caddy * 1 small food caddy Use our [order recycling container service](https://gloucester.gov.uk/bins/order-recycling-containers) to order boxes, lids, sacks and food caddies. ### ğŸ“¸ Photo evidence required You'll need to provide photos of your recycling on your recent collection day (remove lids so recycling can clearly be seen). ## How to apply or renew ### Apply online (quickest way) Online is the quickest way to apply or renew for an extra or larger black bin. [Apply or renew online â†’](https://www.gloucester.gov.uk/environment-waste-recycling/waste-recycling-street-cleaning/bins-recycling/apply-or-renew-an-extra-or-larger-black-bin/) ### ğŸ“ Other ways to apply or renew Please phone us on **[01452 396 396](tel:+441452396396)** if you cannot use the online service. ## What happens next

### â° Decision timeline We aim to provide you with a decision or correspondence within **6 weeks**. We may contact you for more information or a site visit may be required. **Until a decision is made it is your responsibility to manage your extra waste.** ### ğŸ’¡ Need help reducing waste? Most households can manage with a standard black bin by making full use of the recycling service. Check our [recycling guide](https://gloucester.gov.uk/bins/what-goes-where.html) to see what you can recycle. For families with young children, consider the [Real Nappy Project](https://www.gloucester.gov.uk/media/vlqbs2ce/gloucestershire-real-nappy-project.pdf) which can help reduce nappy waste significantly.

title: Garden waste collection | Bins and Recycling | Gloucester City Council
text:
Subscribe to fortnightly garden waste collection in a brown bin. We collect from February to November every year. ## Annual subscription Â£60 per year ğŸ“… February to November (10 months) ğŸ—“ï¸ That's about Â£6 per month during the collection season ## What you get ğŸ—“ï¸ ### Fortnightly collections Regular collections every two weeks from February to November ğŸ—‘ï¸ ### Brown bin provided 240-litre bin delivered free if you don't have one ğŸ“ ### Same day as black bin Collected on alternate weeks to your general waste â° ### Collection window Collected between 7am and 6pm on your scheduled day â„ï¸ ### Winter break included No collections in December and January when waste is minimal ### ğŸ“Œ Important to know **The garden waste service runs annually from 1 February to 30 November.** The subscription is Â£60 per season, and you can join at any time. Your collections will continue until the season ends on 30 November, then you can renew for the next season starting 1 February. ## How it works 1. **Subscribe online** â€” Pay Â£60 by card or Direct Debit 2. **Receive confirmation** â€” We'll email you within 2 working days 3. **Get your brown bin** â€” Delivered within 10 working days 4. **Put it out for collection** â€” Same day as your black bin 5. **We collect it** â€” Every two weeks, February to November 6. **Renew next year** â€” We'll send you a reminder ## What we collect ### âœ“ You can put in your brown bin * Grass cuttings * Lawn clippings * Leaves * Small branches (under 10cm) * Twigs * Hedge trimmings * Plants & flowers * Weeds * Windfall fruit * Dead flower heads

### âœ• Do not put in your brown bin * Soil or turf * Tree stumps or large branches * Japanese knotweed (invasive species) * Diseased plants (put in black bin to prevent spread) * Pet waste * Food waste (use your food caddy instead) * Plant pots, stones or gravel ### ğŸ¢ Don't have a garden? You don't need to subscribe to this service. Use your food caddy for food waste and put houseplant cuttings in your black bin. ## Collection dates ### ğŸ“… 2025 season **Collections run:** 1 February 2025 to 30 November 2025 **Winter break:** December 2025 and January 2026 (no collections) **2026 season starts:** 1 February 2026 We don't collect in December and January because there's very little garden waste in winter. This also gives crews time for vehicle maintenance and helps reduce costs. **Your collection day:** Brown bin collection is on the same day as your black bin, but in alternate weeks. [Check your collection day â†’](https://gloucester.gov.uk/bins/collection-day.html) ## ğŸ’¡ Composting at home You can reduce garden waste and create free compost by composting at home. It's better for your garden and the environment. * **Free** â€” No subscription needed * **Good for your garden** â€” Creates natural fertilizer * **Better for the environment** â€” No transport needed * **Easy to get started** â€” Simple once you know how [Guide to composting at home â†’](https://gloucester.gov.uk/bins/composting-at-home) ## Common questions ### Can I have more than one brown bin? Yes. You pay Â£60 for each additional bin. Subscribe for your first bin, then [order extra bins](https://gloucester.gov.uk/bins/order-bin) separately.

### What if I only want it for part of the year? The subscription covers the full season from 1 February to 30 November. We don't offer part-season subscriptions or refunds if you decide to cancel partway through. Consider whether you'll use the service for most of the season before subscribing. ### What if I move house? If you move within Gloucester, you'll need to take out a new subscription for your new address. The subscription is tied to the property, not to you personally. If you move outside Gloucester, the subscription cannot be transferred or refunded. ### What happens to my garden waste? It's taken to a composting facility where it's turned into soil conditioner used by farmers and gardeners. ### What if my bin isn't collected? Wait until the next working day (crews sometimes run late), then [report a missed collection](https://gloucester.gov.uk/bins/missed-collection.html). We'll return within 2 working days. ### Can I put garden waste in my black bin instead? You can, but your black bin is only collected every two weeks and may fill up quickly. Garden waste can also be composted at home for free.

title: Report a missed collection | Bins and Recycling | Gloucester City Council
text:
We'll return within 2 working days to collect your bin. This service is quick and easy â€” most people complete it in under 2 minutes. **All collections running normally** There are no reported issues affecting collections today. ## Before you report a missed collection **You can report a missed collection if:** * Your bin was due for collection today or yesterday * It's before 4pm on the day after your collection * You put your bin out by 7am on collection day * Your bin was at the edge of your property (where the crew could reach it) * The lid was closed and nothing was sticking out * You didn't have wrong items in your bin (this causes it to be refused) **â° Reporting deadline: 4pm the next business day** Crews update the system as they complete rounds. You can report a missed collection until 4pm the day after your scheduled collection. After that, you'll need to wait for your next scheduled collection. ### Your address Postcode We'll use this to find your address and collection schedule ### Which bins weren't collected? Select all that apply. You can report multiple bins at once. Loading your bins... ### A bit more detail Is there anything else we should know? (optional) This helps us resolve the issue faster. You don't need to explain where you put your bin â€” we already know that. How would you like us to contact you? ## Report received Your reference number is: MB-2025-XXXXX ### What happens next **We'll return within 2 working days** (usually sooner) to collect your bin. Please leave your bin out until it's been collected. If we can't collect your bin (for example, if it contains wrong items), we'll let you know why. ## What if your bin was refused? If your bin has a note or sticker on it, it wasn't collected for one of these reasons: âŒ

### Wrong items inside Contaminated bins can't be collected. Check what should go in each bin. [What goes where â†’](https://gloucester.gov.uk/bins/what-goes-where.html) âš ï¸ ### Lid wouldn't close Overfilled bins or items sticking out prevent safe collection. ğŸš« ### Not accessible Bins behind locked gates or too far from the road can't be reached. âš–ï¸ ### Too heavy Bins that are too heavy create a safety risk for collection crews. **What to do next:** Remove the problem items, then put your bin out on your next scheduled collection day. ## How to prevent missed collections ğŸŒ™ **Put bins out the night before** Collections can start as early as 7am â€” don't risk missing your slot. ğŸ“ **Place at the edge of your property** Position bins where your drive meets the pavement or road. âœ“ **Make sure the lid closes** Don't overfill or force items in â€” lids must close fully. ğŸšª **Keep it accessible** Crews cannot open gates or enter your property. â™»ï¸ ğŸ””

text:
* **ğŸ†• New to Gloucester? Get your first bins** All new residents receive a standard black bin for general waste. You'll need to order your free recycling containers separately. #### ğŸ“ Location Wingmoor Farm, Bishops Cleeve #### ğŸ• Opening hours **Summer:** 9am - 5pm **Winter:** 10am - 4pm **Open:** 7 days a week **Note:** This is the only centre open 7 days a week ## What you can take to recycling centres Household Recycling Centres accept a wide range of materials and items including: Garden waste Cardboard and paper Glass bottles and jars Plastic bottles and containers Metal cans and scrap metal Wood and timber Electrical items Batteries Textiles and clothing Books and media Household furniture Mattresses Fridges and freezers Paint and chemicals Rubble and soil (small amounts) Tyres (limited quantities) **ğŸ’¡ Tip:** For a complete list of what can and cannot be taken, and any restrictions or charges, visit [www.gloucestershirerecycles.com](https://www.gloucestershirerecycles.com/household-recycling-centres-hrcs/) ## Important information ### ğŸš— Van permits If you're visiting in a van, pick-up truck, or large vehicle, you may need a permit. text:

title: Leadership and Structure | Your Council | Gloucester City Council
text:
Gloucester City Council is led by elected councillors and supported by professional officers who work together to deliver services and make decisions that affect our city. ## At a glance 39 Councillors 16 Wards 10 Cabinet Members ## Civic Leadership ### Ancient offices dating back over 800 years The Mayor and Sheriff are ceremonial roles with deep historical roots. The Sheriff was established by King John's Charter in 1200, making it nearly 500 years older than the City Council itself. The first recorded Mayor was Richard the Burgess in 1228. #### ğŸ‘‘ The Mayor (545th) **First citizen of the city** - Chairs Full Council meetings and represents Gloucester at civic, ceremonial and community events. Appointed annually by councillors, the Mayor is a non-political role focused on civic duties. _Current: Councillor Ashley Bowkett (2025)_ #### ğŸ›¡ï¸ The Sheriff (895th) **Deputy Mayor and historic office** - Vice-chairs Full Council and accompanies the Mayor on formal occasions. Originally collected taxes and presided over courts; now a ceremonial role preserving 825 years of Gloucester's history. _Current: Councillor Linda Castle (2025)_ **ğŸ’¡ Did you know?** Gloucester is one of only 15 UK towns and cities that have retained the ancient office of Sheriff, alongside York, Oxford, Canterbury, and Nottingham. ## Political Leadership ### Elected by residents The council is made up of 39 elected councillors who represent the city's 16 wards. Councillors are elected every four years to make decisions on behalf of residents and champion local issues. #### ğŸ›ï¸ The Leader The Leader is elected by councillors and is responsible for the council's overall direction and leadership. The Leader appoints the Cabinet and represents the council publicly. #### ğŸ‘¥ The Cabinet The Cabinet is made up of up to 10 councillors, each with responsibility for specific areas like housing, environment, or finance. They make most major decisions. #### ğŸ—³ï¸ Full Council All 39 councillors meet regularly as Full Council to make key decisions including setting the budget, agreeing major policies, and appointing committees.

#### ğŸ” Overview & Scrutiny Scrutiny councillors hold the Cabinet to account, review decisions, and investigate issues that matter to residents. [View Leader and Cabinet](https://gloucester.gov.uk/your-council/councillors-and-wards/leader-and-cabinet.html) [Find your councillor](https://gloucester.gov.uk/about/councillors.html) ## Officer Structure The council employs around 400 professional officers to deliver services and provide advice to councillors. Officers implement the decisions made by councillors and ensure services run smoothly. #### Chief Executive The Chief Executive is the head of paid service and leads all council officers. They ensure the council operates effectively and delivers on its priorities. #### Corporate Management Team Senior directors responsible for different service areas such as communities, place, and resources. They manage teams and budgets. #### Service Managers Managers lead specific services like planning, housing, environmental services, and customer services. [View senior officer pay](https://gloucester.gov.uk/your-council/how-were-organised/senior-pay-and-staffing.html) ## How Decisions Are Made The council makes decisions through various meetings and committees: * **Cabinet** - Makes most major decisions on services and policies * **Full Council** - Sets the budget and agrees the policy framework * **Planning Committee** - Decides planning applications * **Licensing Committee** - Makes decisions on licences for taxis, alcohol, and entertainment * **Overview & Scrutiny** - Reviews and challenges Cabinet decisions * **Audit & Governance** - Ensures financial controls and good governance

### Public participation Most council meetings are open to the public. You can attend in person, watch online, or even speak at certain meetings to share your views. [Learn how to have your say â†’](https://gloucester.gov.uk/your-council/meetings-and-decisions/have-your-say) [View meeting calendar](https://gloucester.gov.uk/your-council/meetings-and-decisions/calendar.html) [Read our constitution](https://gloucester.gov.uk/your-council/how-were-organised/our-constitution.html)

title: Meeting Calendar | Your Council | Gloucester City Council
text: ## View upcoming council meetings All council meetings are open to the public unless stated otherwise. You can attend in person, watch online, or view agendas and minutes. ### Full meeting calendar For the full interactive calendar with all meetings, agendas, and minutes, visit our democracy pages: [View full calendar on democracy.gloucester.gov.uk](https://democracy.gloucester.gov.uk/) ### Key Meeting Types #### Full Council All 39 councillors meet to make key decisions including setting the budget and agreeing major policies. **Frequency:** Usually monthly **Time:** Typically 6:00pm #### Cabinet The Cabinet makes most of the council's major decisions on services and policy. **Frequency:** Usually monthly **Time:** Typically 6:00pm #### Planning Committee Decides on planning applications that can't be decided by officers. **Frequency:** Usually fortnightly **Time:** Typically 6:00pm #### Overview and Scrutiny Committee Holds the Cabinet to account and reviews council policies and decisions. **Frequency:** Usually monthly **Time:** Typically 6:00pm ### Attending Meetings * **In person:** Most meetings are held at the Eastgate Management Suite, Eastgate Street, Gloucester GL1 1PA * **Online:** Watch live meetings on [our YouTube channel](https://youtube.com/@GloucesterCityCouncil) * **Speak at a meeting:** [Learn how to have your say](https://gloucester.gov.uk/your-council/meetings-and-decisions/have-your-say/speak-at-a-meeting.html) ### Agendas and Minutes All meeting agendas are published at least 5 working days before the meeting. Minutes are published after the meeting. [Search agendas and minutes](https://gloucester.gov.uk/your-council/meetings-and-decisions/agendas-minutes.html)
